headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of James Faucette with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of James Faucette with Morgan Stanley.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just had a couple of quick questions. First, I just want to clarify the comments around QTL and its potential licensing. Should we take from your comments that the risk of potentially falling outside of or below the targeted range for this year have
componenttext: So I just had a couple of quick questions. First, I just want to clarify the comments around QTL and its potential licensing. Should we take from your comments that the risk of potentially falling outside of or below the targeted range for this year have gone up? Or you're just trying to clarify that? And I guess my second question is related, and that is as you continue to pursue licensing agreements with some of the larger Chinese OEMs with whom you don't have agreements, does it reach a stage or when do we reach a stage that you may have to start to pursue legal options through the courts there, and what would that look like?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, James. Yes, so on the range of $7.3 billion to $8 billion, our point was the range was initially defined solely by the outcomes based on our market assumptions at the beginning of the year if we were able to -- if we weren't able to make mu
componenttext: Great. Thanks, James. Yes, so on the range of $7.3 billion to $8 billion, our point was the range was initially defined solely by the outcomes based on our market assumptions at the beginning of the year if we were able to -- if we weren't able to make much progress, we saw ourselves ending up at about $7.3 billion in QTL on the licensing agreements. If we made significant progress, that could take us to $8 billion. Obviously, the LG issue from last quarter created some confusion. We said that was really outside the range. Now that, that has been resolved, what we're saying is that the end market is softer than we had anticipated when we set the range upfront, and that's pulled down the overall size of the market. So we would have to make up some of that in the form of some additional progress on the licensing agreements, and we feel that we're making progress there. So it would be premature to say that we don't believe that we'll end up somewhere in between the $7.3 billion and $8 billion that we started with.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: James, its Derek. On your second question, right now, we're really focused on trying to conclude the remaining agreements through negotiation if that's possible. And I think as you've seen and Steve mentioned and I mentioned in my comments, we've been con
componenttext: James, its Derek. On your second question, right now, we're really focused on trying to conclude the remaining agreements through negotiation if that's possible. And I think as you've seen and Steve mentioned and I mentioned in my comments, we've been continuing to conclude additional agreements over time. So if we get to the point where we don't believe that that's possible through continued negotiation or the companies aren't negotiating in good faith, then we're certainly prepared to take the next step and enforce our rights. With most of the companies, it would really be more along the lines of an action to enforce their agreement that they have in place today. And like I said, we've been preparing for quite some time to do that if necessary. But so far, I have felt like we're still making enough progress with the licensees and I think the progress that you're seeing through the announcements is supportive of that. And so we're going to keep at it and see if we can get across the finish line without the need for litigation, but of course, that's always an option for us if we need it.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2, if I could. Steve, you mentioned chip margins and with regard to thoughts about second sourcing at large customers. Could you talk to us, just expand a little bit about on that, on timing when you think you might see the second sourced at most of
componenttext: Just 2, if I could. Steve, you mentioned chip margins and with regard to thoughts about second sourcing at large customers. Could you talk to us, just expand a little bit about on that, on timing when you think you might see the second sourced at most of your major customers? And on the cost side of it, does there need to be OpEx cuts if there is a second sourcing going on? Or can you handle it without that? And then just one follow-up for Derek on the Chinese. Could you just clarify, there's been a lot of announcements from these large players, have they pretty much all been just adding 3 mode to existing deals? Or have any of those large ones announced been fully incremental? Or again, has it just been those 3 mode additions?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Steve. So on the second sourcing, I think the main point is that we have been assuming that in our plans for really since the beginning of when we did our restructuring. Difficult for me to talk about timing related to that, but I think the p
componenttext: Tim, this is Steve. So on the second sourcing, I think the main point is that we have been assuming that in our plans for really since the beginning of when we did our restructuring. Difficult for me to talk about timing related to that, but I think the point I wanted to communicate was that we are assuming for planning purposes that, that is the case. And even with that, we are comfortable with our margin targets and are improving financials in the chip business in the second half.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, on your second question, I would say, we've commented on this a couple of times and unfortunately, there's still bit a little bit of confusion on the catch-up picture. The most -- as we've said, most of the companies that we've been negotiating with
componenttext: Tim, on your second question, I would say, we've commented on this a couple of times and unfortunately, there's still bit a little bit of confusion on the catch-up picture. The most -- as we've said, most of the companies that we've been negotiating with to try to conclude agreements on the non-3 mode part of the market had been continuing to report and pay under their agreements. And so when we signed them to the new NDRC terms, it doesn't -- that doesn't result in most cases any significant catch-up on the non-3 mode part of the market. As you noted though, in many cases, it will result in them starting to pay royalties and pay past royalties on 3-mode devices that were previously not licensed. It's turned out so far that a number of the players have been the smaller players in the 3-mode market and so the contributions from that haven't been significant or we've -- the way we've structured the deals in how the past royalties have been structured to be paid over time, those are things that will come into our P&L through probably a period of time later in '16 and maybe even into '17. And so we are getting agreements for those to be paid. It's just that they are been probably spread over a longer time than people anticipate. There are less than a handful of companies that we're in negotiations with that are larger players also on 3 mode and non-3 mode that have not been reporting while they're negotiating. And when we conclude those deals, you would expect to see more significant catch-up payments for prior period sales compared to the ones that we've signed to date.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Simona Jankowski with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Simona Jankowski with Goldman Sachs.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you clarify for the June quarter, what is the royalty rate that we should be thinking about? I understand the 2.9% is the longer term number, but just in the near term, given the LG and the China catch-up, how should we think about that for the June q
componenttext: Can you clarify for the June quarter, what is the royalty rate that we should be thinking about? I understand the 2.9% is the longer term number, but just in the near term, given the LG and the China catch-up, how should we think about that for the June quarter?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simona, this is Derek. At this point, we're not going to guide sort of quarter-by-quarter on the implied rate, as I spent a fair amount of time at the Analyst Day going through it. There' so many factors that impact it and the timing of the number of thes
componenttext: Simona, this is Derek. At this point, we're not going to guide sort of quarter-by-quarter on the implied rate, as I spent a fair amount of time at the Analyst Day going through it. There' so many factors that impact it and the timing of the number of these elements, some of which are in our guidance, some of which are not in our guidance because we haven't yet reached closure on it, can have an impact on the rate. We do feel -- continue to feel, as I noted in my script that for the year, for the full fiscal year, that we will be in the range of around the 2.9% that I spoke about at the Analyst Day. So still consistent with that, but you are going to continue to see fluctuations quarter-over-quarter as some of these disputes get resolved or catch-up payments come in. That is going to move. So we're not going to be guiding kind of one quarter out on that.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Switching over to QCT to your 16% margin, can you walk us through kind of revenue per MSM trends? Is the step up at 10% plus going to continue to go higher based on mix shift? And then also, if you could just talk about your momentum in China on the mid- to high-tier, how sustainable do you think that is over a multi-quarter period and what that might do to the revenue premise and trends longer term?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, it's George. We're seeing a lot of factors that supports stronger revenue per MSM growth, not only in the third quarter but also in the fourth quarter, including the lower thin modem. You've got very attractive mix shift between the low tier to the
componenttext: Mike, it's George. We're seeing a lot of factors that supports stronger revenue per MSM growth, not only in the third quarter but also in the fourth quarter, including the lower thin modem. You've got very attractive mix shift between the low tier to the mid and the high tier. All those things will play strongly in revenue per MSM, and we expect that to hold in the third and fourth quarters.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Cristiano. I think to your question on China, I think if you remember in the last earnings call and during the Analyst Day, I think we talked about an interesting trend in China that what's very helpful is transition of the market to the new
componenttext: Mike, this is Cristiano. I think to your question on China, I think if you remember in the last earnings call and during the Analyst Day, I think we talked about an interesting trend in China that what's very helpful is transition of the market to the new version of LTE with carrier aggregation and as well as all mode. I think we're starting to see the strategy materialize not only in this quarter, but as we think about the coming quarters. And this is driving also the mix improvement on the mid and the high tier. We see the mid and high and premium tier in China actually growing faster than the market, that helped drive the mix improvement for QCT.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Hall with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I had 2. One, I wanted to go back to this change in the TRDS unit expectations for the calendar year versus the guidance range for QTL, and just understand, is it -- is the reason that you're not changing the QTL guidance range because these puts
componenttext: I guess I had 2. One, I wanted to go back to this change in the TRDS unit expectations for the calendar year versus the guidance range for QTL, and just understand, is it -- is the reason that you're not changing the QTL guidance range because these puts and takes, you've signed some deals, the market is a little bit weaker than you thought, you just kind of end up in the same midpoint? Or can you give us some more color around why those 2 things seem to differ from each other in terms of movement? And then the second thing I wanted to do, Derek, you mentioned in your commentary, I think, an ecosystem player and expectations for slower upgrade cycle there. Is most of that expectation happening later this year? Are you seeing it happening now? Can you just clarify that, what your definition of ecosystem player, is that a vendor or is that a particular region of the world? Just give us a little bit more clarity there.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rod, yes, so let met try to take the first one on. So really, what we're seeing is, if we look at the market for calendar '16 and '15 came in just slightly lower than what we expected for the year. We are seeing some softness in the premium tier, some kin
componenttext: Rod, yes, so let met try to take the first one on. So really, what we're seeing is, if we look at the market for calendar '16 and '15 came in just slightly lower than what we expected for the year. We are seeing some softness in the premium tier, some kind of puts and takes, some other weakness in emerging regions, but actually improvement in China. China continues to be quite strong. And overall, also the ASP picture is looking good as well. We expected moderation in the ASP declines year-over-year and that seems to be at least so far tracking better than our assumption. So we do feel like there is a -- the net-net of that is a bit weaker market for the fiscal year, but we gave a pretty wide range on QTL revenue for the year, just given all the different elements in there. And we felt with still some time left in the year, we do believe we can continue to make progress in China, as we have been demonstrating over the last few months. And so as George mentioned, just felt it was premature to adjust the range. We will need to make more progress relative to where we were before, just given the change in the market, but we still think the range is a reasonable range to hold for now. On the second question, really I think what we're seeing is we are seeing some continued softness in the premium tier. We saw that earlier and our projections were based on that. There's a little bit more softness and I think that sort of plays out and has played out through some of the previous quarters already and will continue through the year.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: It's 2 related questions. Just when you talk about that with the second sourcing, that you had a good idea and had rightsized the OpEx. That there is going to be second source, would you have an idea of what percentage you'll get? And kind of second part of is, as you look forward into next year, you've always been ahead on the modem, but here is a top-tier phone using someone else's. Can you just talk about sustainability as the leading-edge, and talk about what percentage of the market actually uses the Cat 12 modems, whether that increases over time?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Blayne, this is Steve. I'll take the first part, and maybe Cristiano can jump in on the long-term question. I think we took an appropriate planning assumption really for sizing the OpEx. We wanted to make sure that when we implemented our realignment in t
componenttext: Blayne, this is Steve. I'll take the first part, and maybe Cristiano can jump in on the long-term question. I think we took an appropriate planning assumption really for sizing the OpEx. We wanted to make sure that when we implemented our realignment in terms of cost structure, that we comprehended, I think, the proper range of outcomes. I think we feel quite strong or quite good about our modem road map and where it's going, but I think we're doing the appropriate thing from the perspective of planning our OpEx. And maybe Cristiano could add some of the product details of that.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Cristiano. Look, I think what's important to understand, when we think about technology not only in the modem space but even on the MSM, I think we continue to maintain at least 2 generations lead over the competition, but I think more important i
componenttext: This is Cristiano. Look, I think what's important to understand, when we think about technology not only in the modem space but even on the MSM, I think we continue to maintain at least 2 generations lead over the competition, but I think more important is some of the transitions and trends we're seeing in the market. I think one of the things is the -- more the Internet is becoming wireless and you see the 4G transition becoming more mature in developed markets, you see carriers now are competing for premium customers. And the transition that we've been talking about LTE to carrier aggregation, that is actually going faster. So I think you're starting to see gigabit LTE modem that we demonstrated, and we will see from that one [indiscernible] licensing spectrum with the global standard, I think, was mentioned by Steve, the LAA. And maybe within the next 2 to 3 years, an accelerated timeline of deployment of 5G. As we continue to invest and we see those technologies transitions ahead of us, we feel very confident that the whole nature of the market was probably going to demand the latest technology in the key devices. So that's how we feel about the market and our modem business.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kulbinder, this is Derek. On your first question, I think you got the numbers right. The chart that we showed at the Analyst Day was, again, for fiscal 2016 basically just in your revenue, no catch-up from prior periods. And we said, if we completed these
componenttext: Kulbinder, this is Derek. On your first question, I think you got the numbers right. The chart that we showed at the Analyst Day was, again, for fiscal 2016 basically just in your revenue, no catch-up from prior periods. And we said, if we completed these remaining negotiations with the handful of companies we have left, that would get us to about 75%-ish collection rate on the TRDS, but that we would continue to have compliance issues that we're going to need to work through. And that really is going to be something that we hope to make progress on and expect to make progress on as we move through '16, but certainly will also be a longer term project. This is -- just there's a fair amount of work involved in it and it's going to take some time. So I think the way to look at it is if we can achieve the results that we hope in the negotiations, we'll have a meaningful step function up on the collections, but to get to the remainder of that 25%-ish is going to take some time.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Cristiano. I think -- maybe to address the question on share, I think we -- maybe to decompose the question in different segments. One, if you look on the premium tier, we have been -- there has been a number of announcements. We have been very co
componenttext: This is Cristiano. I think -- maybe to address the question on share, I think we -- maybe to decompose the question in different segments. One, if you look on the premium tier, we have been -- there has been a number of announcements. We have been very confident in the Snapdragon 820. I think we made a lot of progress there. I think even if you look with one of the large customers, both the Samsung Galaxy S7 and S7 Edge that launched in the second fiscal quarter have been using the Snapdragon 820, and I think we have about 117 designs. We feel good about that portfolio. And in China, if you look what happened when China entered 4G, we had -- when we started a transition to 4G, we expected -- over time, we started with very high share, we expected that to normalize over time, but what we're seeing actually in this year, we're doing better than we expected in share in China. And also seeing the impact of those technologies changing the product mix from growth being higher from the low to the mid- and high-tier, showing the modem continues to be a good point of differentiation, even in the growth market like China. I think maybe to clarify this, I believe we have said early in the year, as we went through the SRP, that we were planning so that we could de-risk the market concentration in our planning assumptions. I think that's what we're saying. We're planning that -- we have some planning assumptions, but at the end of the day, we're still designing a very competitive product road map. And we're seeing good traction to marketplace, not only on the modem but the MSM premium tier and the product portfolio that we have been commercializing in China.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Arcuri with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Arcuri with Cowen & Company.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. I guess, first of all, question for all of you. Do you worry that we're sort of talking about share loss at the premium tier? And there's some consensus sort of as who you're going to lose that to on the chip side, and of course, they make their
componenttext: I have 2. I guess, first of all, question for all of you. Do you worry that we're sort of talking about share loss at the premium tier? And there's some consensus sort of as who you're going to lose that to on the chip side, and of course, they make their own chips. So do you worry that, that becomes sort of a competitive disadvantage over time, having access to world-class manufacturing, that your foundry partners is right behind and able to keep up?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Steve. I think a couple of things. One is just to reiterate that from the purpose of when we plan OpEx and our margin trajectory, we do assume that something will happen, but we're quite confident in our road map. Now, right now, our products
componenttext: Tim, this is Steve. I think a couple of things. One is just to reiterate that from the purpose of when we plan OpEx and our margin trajectory, we do assume that something will happen, but we're quite confident in our road map. Now, right now, our products that we are competing against are really not manufactured by -- it's not a vertical play in terms of who we're going after. And then specifically, when you look at our foundry partners, they were very happy with what we're seeing from a transistor road map out in time, actually from multiple sources. So we feel not only can we compete in the modem tier and the connectivity tiers, but even more importantly, in computing and even computing going into very high-performance computing, we have the transistors to be able to make that successful. So I think we feel very confident both in transistor road map that we're seeing from our suppliers and also with the business model that we will be in a strong position. I think also our scale within the fabless industry is actually helping us a lot in terms of pricing. I think that's one of the things you're seeing the benefit of in terms of some of the margin improvement that you're seeing embedded in the business in the second half and even delivered out here in the second quarter.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. The first one on the QTL licensing guide, I got to be honest, I still don't understand why you're guiding like you're guiding. If I understand what you're saying, you need to get more collection now, but if your trends of collection, the range o
componenttext: I have 2. The first one on the QTL licensing guide, I got to be honest, I still don't understand why you're guiding like you're guiding. If I understand what you're saying, you need to get more collection now, but if your trends of collection, the range of collection right now was the same today as it was when you first gave the guidance, what would the guidance range be? I mean what are we talking about here? Secondly, it seems to me like you are implicity guiding your QTL margins, your operating margins into the mid-17s ph] for the next quarter, which is low -- lower than seasonal. And I know you said you had some increasing legal and litigation costs, which I assume is what's driving that. So are these compliance related? Or is there something else going on, on the legal and litigation front that's taking the QTL operating margins down next quarter?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stacy, this is Derek. I mean if you look at the Q3 guidance, I think our view has been that we're not going to include in guidance in quarter deals unless we have clear line of sight to those and they're essentially either done or close to done. And so we
componenttext: Stacy, this is Derek. I mean if you look at the Q3 guidance, I think our view has been that we're not going to include in guidance in quarter deals unless we have clear line of sight to those and they're essentially either done or close to done. And so we've been taking a more conservative approach maybe than we had in the past and we've been doing that for a couple of quarters now. And I guess you see the guide in Q3 is consistent with that. And I think really if stepping back and looking, the difference may be just in terms of the assumptions in timing, if I look at some of the other models out there in terms of what lands in Q3 versus Q4. We've -- because of the way we're guiding, that would essentially mean that more is in Q4 versus Q3 if you look at the profile for the year, assuming we're able to conclude those remaining deals. That may be part of it. On the margin question, I just think you're -- I'm not sure how you got to your number, that's not consistent with what we're modeling in the business.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just -- I would add that yes, that will be well below our assumption for QTL in any of the remaining quarters. And I think what we've seen is on some of these licensing arrangements, they can be large and lumpy and trying to forecast what is
componenttext: Yes, I would just -- I would add that yes, that will be well below our assumption for QTL in any of the remaining quarters. And I think what we've seen is on some of these licensing arrangements, they can be large and lumpy and trying to forecast what is inherently in negotiation process proved over a number of quarters to be something that either, one, was hard to do or, two, created unnecessary negotiating leverage. And so I think we'll stick with this process, but we have said for the full year in the $7.3 billion to $8 billion, that we'll have to conclude some activity on the licensing front to get back within that range because of the softness in the market.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tal Liani with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tal Liani with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to understand 2 things. First, the contribution of LG this quarter. When you guided for the quarter, I think that LG was not in. And I'm trying to understand how much of the strength this quarter is related to the addition of LG versus [indiscern
componenttext: I wanted to understand 2 things. First, the contribution of LG this quarter. When you guided for the quarter, I think that LG was not in. And I'm trying to understand how much of the strength this quarter is related to the addition of LG versus [indiscernible] and how much is the underlying market? And then second, this is a broader question. You're down -- your QTL is down 11.6% year-over-year, and I know there was a catch-up payment last year. But if I look at the -- if I look at -- kind of think about things at the high level, China was not in past quarter outside of the catch-up payment, I think, from Huawei. This year, this quarter, you do have China in, you also have LG in. So why are we seeing -- we don't need much higher contribution of China just on a like-for-like basis. Again, the TRDS between the 2 quarters is down 7.5%, but real revenues are down 11.6%. So you're down more than the TRDS, that's even happening given the China is kicking in this year. So I'm just trying to understand the dynamics of China contribution and why isn't there a much stronger take or much stronger revenue level than we are seeing right now?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tal, just to be clear, the LG settlement happened in our third quarter, so it is not in the second quarter numbers. It will be a 200 -- roughly $200 million. We said it's a couple of hundred -- or $100 million, roughly $100 million a quarter for the first
componenttext: Tal, just to be clear, the LG settlement happened in our third quarter, so it is not in the second quarter numbers. It will be a 200 -- roughly $200 million. We said it's a couple of hundred -- or $100 million, roughly $100 million a quarter for the first 2 quarters, that'll be catch-up, that's embedded in our guidance. And then we'll be back to a run rate with LG, but that's all in Q3. Really the Q2 items that we talked about was the fact that you had the ALU agreement, which added approximately $250 million. And then we had seen the discontinuation of a licensing amortization that was about $100 million in that quarter. Derek, did you want to comment on...

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think just to add to what George said, I think really the -- what we said about LG was it's -- in the quarters we talked about, it's been more than $100 million per quarter. So as George said, that is not in Q2. That will be reflected in Q3, both t
componenttext: Yes. I think just to add to what George said, I think really the -- what we said about LG was it's -- in the quarters we talked about, it's been more than $100 million per quarter. So as George said, that is not in Q2. That will be reflected in Q3, both the in quarter activity for Q3 as well as 2 quarters -- 2 prior quarters of catch-up. In terms of trying to look -- do the walk between last year Q2 to this year, George hit on some of that. Obviously, we've got kind of a onetime event in Q2 this quarter with the acceleration of the licensee fee that came in, the $266 million-ish payment, but then being offset by the fact that LG revenues are deferred, they're not in the quarter. And then we also have the end of this $100 million-ish a quarter amortization that's reflected in this quarter. Plus as you mentioned a year ago, we had some catch-up payments of about $150 million from the resolution of a prior dispute. And then the China contribution, China was reflected pretty strongly in the year-ago quarter, meaning that was the last quarter that was reported to us before the NDRC resolution, the effect of that took hold in January of 2015. And so one of the other issues you're dealing with, with the year-over-year comparison is you've got application of the NDRC terms now in this quarter. That wasn't a factor a year ago as well as we saw the amount of units that are being underreported accelerate throughout the year last year, in particular related to these negotiations where licensees stopped paying, and that was not really a primary driver in the year-ago quarter. So I think that's kind of the walk is probably best we can break it out.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tavis McCourt with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tavis McCourt with Raymond James.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple from me. First, on the MSM guidance -- unit guidance for next quarter. So if I look at that on a year-over-year basis, it's down kind of high-teens, and obviously, you're gaining some share at a major customer. I assume all of that cannot be rela
componenttext: A couple from me. First, on the MSM guidance -- unit guidance for next quarter. So if I look at that on a year-over-year basis, it's down kind of high-teens, and obviously, you're gaining some share at a major customer. I assume all of that cannot be related to unit weakness at the other major customer. And yet everything I hear so fair is China's good, China's good. So help me with the disconnect. What's driving that unit growth in light of some share gains at one of your -- or unit decline year-over-year in light of some share gains at one of your larger customers? And then secondly, to help me get to that 16% operating margin guidance for June, should we expect a more material change in the R&D or SG&A line item as we go from Q3 to Q4 than we've seen earlier this year?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the MSMs, as we look at year-over-year, there's definitely a significant delta from one major customer that is contributing. And what you're seeing in China is a shift in low entry to mid and high. And so it's one of the reasons why you're seeing
componenttext: Sure. On the MSMs, as we look at year-over-year, there's definitely a significant delta from one major customer that is contributing. And what you're seeing in China is a shift in low entry to mid and high. And so it's one of the reasons why you're seeing strong pickup in revenue per MSM in the quarter. So it's a story more of mix shift. And it's pretty neutral outside of that. And so at the low -- the low tier units tend to be more of those low tier units that we're trading off, but we're picking up a significant amount of mid-high. In terms of OpEx, we expect OpEx to continue to decrease into the fourth quarter, but I think some of the comparisons that you may be doing would be looking at R&D period-over-period, but in one period, we didn't have the CSR OpEx and the other period we do. So just make sure you're doing an apples-to-apples comparison, because we've already seen a fair amount of the reduction already in the base level of OpEx.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess 2 questions. First on OpEx, your fiscal year guide implies OpEx down 7% in September. Curious if that's right, and what we should think about going into the December quarter? And then secondly, with a nice uplift to ASPs for MSM in the June quarte
componenttext: I guess 2 questions. First on OpEx, your fiscal year guide implies OpEx down 7% in September. Curious if that's right, and what we should think about going into the December quarter? And then secondly, with a nice uplift to ASPs for MSM in the June quarter, curious how we should think about that heading into the back half of the calendar year as you layer in both the high end as well as mid-level handsets?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What we said for the full year on OpEx, if you just look at the reported numbers, we'll be down 2% to 4%, but we have about a 5% impact from acquisitions. So we'd be down in the range of 7% to 9% year-over-year. And as I said, we would continue to ex
componenttext: Yes. What we said for the full year on OpEx, if you just look at the reported numbers, we'll be down 2% to 4%, but we have about a 5% impact from acquisitions. So we'd be down in the range of 7% to 9% year-over-year. And as I said, we would continue to expect some cost reduction continuing through the back half of the year, just on some of the actions that have taken place. In terms of revenue for MSM, as I said earlier, I think the dynamics that are driving the significant pickup that we are seeing in Q3 remain in place for Q4. Very good mix, strong demand for our premium tier. Again shift from low tier into the mid and high-tier. And then some softness certainly comparatively year-over-year on thin modem volumes, which tend to depress revenues for MSM.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, you said that forecasted QCT margins included expectations for second source of your largest customers. Are we to imply from that statement that the mere mention of it, it means that it will be material and either you miss the margins? Or do you se
componenttext: Steve, you said that forecasted QCT margins included expectations for second source of your largest customers. Are we to imply from that statement that the mere mention of it, it means that it will be material and either you miss the margins? Or do you see it more as a headline miss? And then along the same lines, we are talking about Intel. Is it true that every modem they've shipped so far has been that of TSMC, but is your calculus on competition or market share change, if they move that modem into their own process or does it have no bearing at all on your outlook?

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, I think that on the second question, it really doesn't bear much to it. I mean, the modem business is all about feature leadership and RF and it's really about technology breadth and technology complexity. It tends to be less about die size and those
componenttext: Ed, I think that on the second question, it really doesn't bear much to it. I mean, the modem business is all about feature leadership and RF and it's really about technology breadth and technology complexity. It tends to be less about die size and those things. And first to market, first to market with complexity tends to be the thing that leads the most. I think on your first question, it's really a communication of a planning assumption and also confidence in us meeting our long-term trajectory, both in this year and outside of this year with that assumption. And I think it's important to make sure people understand that. We do feel very confident though in our position in the modem segment.

headline: QUALCOMM Incorporated, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you. I want to thank everyone for attending the call today. We had a stronger-than-expected quarter and are executing well on our plans to position the company for the next phase of profitable growth. We continue to make good progress on the li
componenttext:
Yes. Thank you. I want to thank everyone for attending the call today. We had a stronger-than-expected quarter and are executing well on our plans to position the company for the next phase of profitable growth. We continue to make good progress on the licensing side in China and this remains a key focus area for the company. We are also seeing positive impact of new product releases in QCT, along with the efficiency gains from our realignment program. 
In closing, I want to thank our employees for their hard work and commitment, as we move forward to capture the many exciting opportunities ahead. Thank you.
